navbar.logoAlt: Logo - Open book, with waves on the pages and an aqueduct in the background

paragraph.TextIntro: The Tale of Water is an event that won the Concours Public Artes et Iubilaeum - 2025. A project of the Ciel'in città Cultural Association, conceived together with Adriana Polveroni and curated by Adriana Polveroni...
paragraph.TextFull:
This event proposes to explore the symbolic, cultural and environmental value of water through artistic languages, participatory journeys and interventions in certain neighborhoods of Rome. The exhibition consists of a series of free-entry appointments, works and activities with the participation of artists, students, local communities and pilgrims, in view of the Jubilee 2025 which will take place from September to November 2025.

The theme of water constitutes the center of the entire event, approached in a dual register: as a founding element of the history of Rome and a source of inspiration for the artistic imagination; and as a precious natural resource, increasingly at the center of contemporary reflections related to union, sharing and sustainability.

Based on these assumptions, the project identifies as places of intervention an aqueduct and adjacent areas - green spaces, symbolic sites, public and private contexts - in the south-east area of the city as sites for intervention.

appointment1.CriticTextTitle:
LIQUEFACTIONS or The forms of water
by Bruno Di Marino
appointment1.CriticTextIntro:
Water is one of the key elements of both experimental cinema and video art and media art.
For only one reason: its fluidity.
Water is a continuous flow but, above all, it changes incessantly of state, from liquid to solid to aeriform...
appointment1.CriticTextFull:
Water is one of the key elements of both experimental cinema and video art and media art.
For only one reason: its fluidity.
Water is a continuous flow but, above all, it changes incessantly of state, from liquid to solid to aeriform.
And was it not Gilles Deleuze who defined experimental moving images as something gaseous and pulsating?
The transformations of matter are at the heart of the audiovisual experience not necessarily conditioned by a narrative structure but, indeed, able to enchant and hypnotize the spectator precisely through the intermittent muting.

This exhibition, which we wanted to title Liquefactions, presents a series of works starting from the historical avant-garde, an early period in which the artist’s film is configured more akin to painting and music, rather than theater and literature, as the futurists wanted.
To then reach the present day, when by now with the digitization of the image we have reached the total dematerialization of it.
And after all, the numerical status of cinema is the final stage of a fluidification process that has shown us the infinite passages of a condition of permanent instability of the imaginary.

Video art, even more than research cinema, has been associated with the liquid element always for that idea of unstoppable fluidity which is at the basis of its nature, with the possibility to sculpt reality and to repropose it on screen (the monitor initially with its delimited frame) by electromagnetic waves.
Paik’s experiments of deformation in real time by applying magnets to the cathode tube are one of the first examples of modification of the television stream, under the sign of a process composed of distortions and liquefactions that lead us from the figurative into the realm of abstraction, from sense to non-sense.

The way in which the works are presented is not, however, a detail, a secondary element in constructing a programme on this theme.
Meanwhile we decided to overcome the distinctions between works thought as 'mono-channel', installation works and works that document (in part) performances taken place in a given space and time.
Indeed, the core of the programme is to reflect on all the forms that water can take, including the states (and stages) not only of matter but also of audiovisual genres, including scientific documentaries (Painlevé) and visual symphonies.

Moreover, apart from the evenings in which a selection of films/videos (who can now distinguish between these two typologies? Better to define them as audiovisual works in a broader sense) is reproposed on a normal screen, perpetuating a vocation to see that belongs to 20th century, we thought of projecting the images directly on the walls of one of the many aqueducts that draw engineering geometries loaded with history and knowledge on the vast Roman territory that stretches from the center to the outskirts, not only of the city but of the Empire.
Water, In short, it returns to water, indeed to its original device that allowed a civilization to systematically equip itself with a vital element.

Projecting audiovisual works that have as subject water directly on the wall structure of an aqueduct, is not just a mere self-referential game, but an amplification of the medium and the work itself.
Of course the stones and bricks of this millenarian architecture tend to absorb the images, to appropriate them by changing their contours.
But it is the incorporation that adds value and makes even more significant the transformations of water transcribed on film or represented in digital.
It is not a question of establishing yet another trivial and inflated video mapping.
While bending to the support, the images nevertheless oppose resistance to the aqueduct-screen, which ideally carries them, accentuating a flow shape that seems to have neither beginning nor end.
Good vision.

appointment5.name: The Beauty of Water
appointment5.description2: Creation of works themed on water and its sustainability.

descriptionMK.TextIntro: Mercedes Klausner (Argentina 1991), has for years been carrying out work focused on memory through site-specific interventions that see the use of light for the projection of images drawn on glass...
descriptionMK.TextFull:
Mercedes Klausner (Argentina 1991), has for years been carrying out work focused on memory through site-specific interventions that see the use of light for the projection of images drawn on glasswith fragments of dust recovered from debris from disappeared places.
For the occasion, the artist will be hosted in residence by Pianobi and accompanied by Isabella Vitale as curator, for the creation of a work that sees the use of dust obtained from debris recovered at the foot of the Felice aqueduct.
This intervention will result in works capable of producing images that will be projected onto the walls of the Pianobi project.

appointment5.time1:
Curated by Isabella Vitale
Opening on 4 October
at 7 PM
PROGETTO PIANOBI
Via dei Ciceri, 97-99
municipio VII

appointment6.CriticTextTitle:
LIQUEFACTIONS or The forms of water
by Bruno Di Marino
appointment6.CriticTextIntro:
Water is one of the key elements of both experimental cinema and video art and media art.
For only one reason: its fluidity.
Water is a continuous flow but, above all, it changes incessantly of state, from liquid to solid to aeriform...
appointment6.CriticTextFull:
Water is one of the key elements of both experimental cinema and video art and media art.
For only one reason: its fluidity.
Water is a continuous flow but, above all, it changes incessantly of state, from liquid to solid to aeriform.
And was it not Gilles Deleuze who defined experimental moving images as something gaseous and pulsating?
The transformations of matter are at the heart of the audiovisual experience not necessarily conditioned by a narrative structure but, indeed, able to enchant and hypnotize the spectator precisely through the intermittent muting.

This exhibition, which we wanted to title Liquefactions, presents a series of works starting from the historical avant-garde, an early period in which the artist’s film is configured more akin to painting and music, rather than theater and literature, as the futurists wanted.
To then reach the present day, when by now with the digitization of the image we have reached the total dematerialization of it.
And after all, the numerical status of cinema is the final stage of a fluidification process that has shown us the infinite passages of a condition of permanent instability of the imaginary.

Video art, even more than research cinema, has been associated with the liquid element always for that idea of unstoppable fluidity which is at the basis of its nature, with the possibility to sculpt reality and to repropose it on screen (the monitor initially with its delimited frame) by electromagnetic waves.
Paik’s experiments of deformation in real time by applying magnets to the cathode tube are one of the first examples of modification of the television stream, under the sign of a process composed of distortions and liquefactions that lead us from the figurative into the realm of abstraction, from sense to non-sense.

The way in which the works are presented is not, however, a detail, a secondary element in constructing a programme on this theme.
Meanwhile we decided to overcome the distinctions between works thought as 'mono-channel', installation works and works that document (in part) performances taken place in a given space and time.
Indeed, the core of the programme is to reflect on all the forms that water can take, including the states (and stages) not only of matter but also of audiovisual genres, including scientific documentaries (Painlevé) and visual symphonies.

Moreover, apart from the evenings in which a selection of films/videos (who can now distinguish between these two typologies? Better to define them as audiovisual works in a broader sense) is reproposed on a normal screen, perpetuating a vocation to see that belongs to 20th century, we thought of projecting the images directly on the walls of one of the many aqueducts that draw engineering geometries loaded with history and knowledge on the vast Roman territory that stretches from the center to the outskirts, not only of the city but of the Empire.
Water, In short, it returns to water, indeed to its original device that allowed a civilization to systematically equip itself with a vital element.

Projecting audiovisual works that have as subject water directly on the wall structure of an aqueduct, is not just a mere self-referential game, but an amplification of the medium and the work itself.
Of course the stones and bricks of this millenarian architecture tend to absorb the images, to appropriate them by changing their contours.
But it is the incorporation that adds value and makes even more significant the transformations of water transcribed on film or represented in digital.
It is not a question of establishing yet another trivial and inflated video mapping.
While bending to the support, the images nevertheless oppose resistance to the aqueduct-screen, which ideally carries them, accentuating a flow shape that seems to have neither beginning nor end.
Good vision.

descriptionPA.name: The Beauty of Water
descriptionPA.description2: Creation of works themed on water and its sustainability.
descriptionPA.time2:
Curated by Adriana Polveroni
Opening on 14 November
from 3.30 PM to 8.00 PM
Laghetto di Roma Vecchia
Via Lemoni 279
municipio VII
descriptionPA.TextIntro: The Mist Fountain is a site-specific work by Paolo Assenza created for the project curated by Adriana Polveroni The Tale of Water, promoted by the ’ Ciel'in città Cultural Association and winner of the Artes et Iubilaeum – 2025 call...
descriptionPA.TextFull:
The Mist Fountain is a site-specific work by Paolo Assenza created for the project curated by Adriana Polveroni The Tale of Water, promoted by the ’ Ciel'in città Cultural Association and winner of the Artes et Iubilaeum – 2025 call.

The sculpture consists of a concave cone made of cast aluminum supported by three elements that support it above the body of water of the Vecchia Roma lake near the Parco degli Acquedotti.

The mist fountain does not function like a traditional fountain: it does not flow water from a spring or system, but is activated thanks to the natural phenomenon of condensation.
Air moisture settles on the metal surface after sunset and, dripping through a hole at the top of the mold, falls onto the surface of the pond, temporarily rippling the water.

The work is designed to connect with an imperceptible and often overlooked dimension of water: the gaseous, invisible one, which manifests itself only when the conditions of the natural world allow it.The sculpture does not impose a flow, does not control or distribute the water as happens in a traditional fountain, but adapts to the rhythm of the atmospheric phenomenon, returning a slow time, made up of waits and apparitions.

The drops generated by condensation do not only represent a passage of physical state, but become a sign of a transformation, of an energy that becomes visible at the instant in which falls into the lake.The vibration that is produced on the surface of the body of water is minimal, fragile, but sufficient to modify the perception of the landscape and to make the interaction between natural elements and artistic intervention tangible.

The fountain of mist is therefore not a device that celebrates the power of water, but a work that invites us to perceive its delicacy, to dwell on its becoming, on the ephemeral nature of a gesture that happens only if the world allows it.

It is in this departure from the monumentality of the classical fountain that a poetic space opens up: a place where water tells its story through its metamorphoses, from the invisible breath of air to the trace that ripples the surface of the pond.

Work visible until December 9, 2025. (After sunset it is recommended to bring a flashlight and follow the routes to the pond).

description.TextIntro: A fountain, a site-specific work conceived in the operational headquarters of the Pianobi Arte Contemporanea project will be created by Laurent Le Deunff (France 1977), a French visual artist based in Bordeaux...
description.TextFull:
A fountain, a site-specific work conceived in the operational headquarters of the Pianobi Arte Contemporanea project will be created by Laurent Le Deunff (France 1977), a French visual artist based in Bordeaux.

Le Deunff has been sculpting for over twenty years, creating sculptures, stylized anthropomorphic and zoomorphic representations with magical power, as well as complex installations capable of transforming an enclosed space into a natural setting with strong evocative power, replenishing versatile, ecological and recycled materials such as earth, sand, wood, lime and paper.

Laurent le Deunff, during his residency at the Pianobi operational headquarters, will create a zoomorphic fountain. The work will be accessible to a diverse audience of professionals and non-professionals, including pilgrims who have come to Rome for the Jubilee. Visitors will be invited to express their personal wish through the ritual gesture of throwing one of the created coins into the fountain.

appointment6.name2: Of the night, of the Tears, of the Dawn

appointment6.time2: Presentation of the preparatory sketches for the monument created by Alfredo Pirri in honor of the priest

description.TextIntro:
Taken from the name of the flamenco school founded by Don Sardelli in 1982, the public monument, which I propose to realize, already exists in its material structure.
It is an electric trellis installed on the arch of the aqueduct next to the fountain of Clement XII that characterizes the entrance of via del Mandrione...
description.TextFull:
Taken from the name of the flamenco school founded by Don Sardelli in 1982, the public monument, which I propose to realize, already exists in its material structure.
It is an electric trellis installed on the arch of the aqueduct next to the fountain of Clement XII that characterizes the entrance of via del Mandrione.
This element was left there by the Superintendence, during the last restoration works of the aqueducts, a testimony of a past characterized by the arrival of vital supports (electricity, water...) for the citizens of the time who lived in the huts frequented by Don Sardelli who animated their struggles to obtain these essential benefits.
My intervention would be limited to exalt the cross shape of this lattice by gilding in gold leaf or golden paint and positioning a light that makes it possible to see at night.
Will be presented the photos of the intervention site and sketches of the work. The lattice in question is visible from via Tuscolana and for a good stretch of via del Mandrione.
The light, suggested in the sketches by white lines, will be projected by a lighthouse placed on the pole of light (ACEA) already present on the road (via del Mandrione).
Alfredo Pirri
